column4: I am having problems with audio on my newly installed Ubuntu. I am using a Sony Vaio and am not getting any audio at all (it worked fine previously in Windows 7). I have tried basic fixes such as adjusting volume levels, using the system controls, etc. Any advice on how I can fix the problem, or, if necessary, switch to an audio driver that Ubuntu can support?
by chance, is PCM muted?
you know in windows how in your advanced volume control you have volume in 1 slider, and wav in another slider, and if either is muted, you have ZERO sound?
thats kind of like PCM/volume in linux. Two individual sliders, both need to be set appropriately or itll be muted.
its just a quick thought, I have no idea if itll help, but lets make sure... are you on ubuntu 10.04?
hm, in the GUI I'm not sure where it's located in 10.04. They must have moved it from where I previously remember it.
open a terminal and type "alsamixer" and hit enter
you should see several sliders. PCM (for me) is the 2nd slider over. Is it muted?
what does it say for "master"
master slider says 00 and it has a colored bar running all the way to the top
under the PCM slider, there is an icon just above the 100 <> 100 you saw
itll either say MM, or have a green square with 00 in it. Whcih is it?
ah, for me its the opposite - I have nothing for master, but for pcm I have that option. That's probably because pcm may be listed as your primary audio adjustment device.
let me think a minute...
highlight the master slider, and bring it up to about 30
then play some sort of audio and see if you hear output
is there a "MM" under master?
and PCM has 00 in the box and is maxed?
ahhh thats right. I forgot you said that.
what kind of sound card do you have
is this a laptop?
hmm... I'm not too sure bro. All I know to check for is the obvious things (muted, etc) and the PCM + Master, making sure both are NOT muted and both have adequate sound level.
for example, when I hit volume up/down, it changes master. AS a result, I leave PCM maxed @ 100
